page.title: 17 ECOLOGY : EAST SHEEN
page.content: Richmond Park is a large Royal park with many different types of trees - oak, elm, beech, hawthorn, willow and cherry. The oldest are oaks; many of the young trees are protected by fence guards. Wildlife includes many Red and Fallow Deer as well as rabbits, foxes, squirrels; birds include moorhens, coots, duck and pigeons. Fish are found in Beverley Brook. In the general area of Sheen, most streets are lined with limes and cherries. There are large areas of grass and flowering plants, many species having 'strayed' from cultivated gardens. Some moss and fungi are found on walls. The quality of the environment has recently been improved by the work of the Keep Richmond Tidy Group. In 1984, we won the a national K.B.T. award.
